sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Hello and welcome to euronews tonight. Here are some of our top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Omicron advances globally at a rapid pace.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: What experts believe is the most aggressive and fastest spreading coronavirus variant is putting Europe on edge.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Italy going hard after the unvaccinated.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: New measures aim to exclude them from many public events and services.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Olaf Scholz appoints MP and prominent epidemiologist Karl Lauterbach as Germany's new health minister, a strong advocate of mandatory vaccinations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And Myanmar's deposed leader Aung San Suu Kyi gets a two-year jail sentence, the first verdict in a series of cases that could send her to prison for decades.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Welcome to the program, I'm Stefan Grobe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The Omicron variant that's now been detected in nearly 40 countries around the world could become the dominant COVID strain within weeks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Russia, Croatia, Nepal and Argentina all reported their first cases on Monday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: U.S. health officials say the variant has spread to at least 16 states.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: New York says private employers will be asked to mandate COVID vaccines for employees.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: South Africa, where Omicron was first detected, is preparing hospitals for further admissions, as case numbers push the country into a fourth COVID-19 wave. Poland's prime minister says new tighter COVID restrictions will be announced this week. Compulsory jabs for certain professions and vaccine certificates could be among some of the measures being introduced. Poland has seen an increase in infections. Only 54% of people in Poland have been fully vaccinated. People wanting to go to a bar, a restaurant, a cinema in Italy will have to show proof of vaccination or proof of having recently recovered from COVID-19. The so-called super green pass is also now required at sporting events and clubs. The tightening of measures also include fines for those found without a valid pass or a negative test on public transport. 80% of people in Italy have been fully immunized so far, with 15% having received a third dose of the COVID jab. Joining me now from Rome is our correspondent,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Giorgia Orlandi. Giorgia, good evening and good to see you. So Italy has already asked every worker to have the basic green pass. What is changing now?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Well, hi, Stefan. Well, despite the fact that over 80% of the population has been fully vaccinated, it seems that the government is still determined to continue to clamp down on the no-vax movement, the no-green-pass movement. and despite the fact that the overall number of covet cases has increased here in italy the government says the situation is under control and there's no need to make vaccination compulsory now the new measures which according to italy's prime minister mario draghi are needed to preserve what he calls normality to give a certainty to the tourist holiday season coming to effect today and will last until the 15th of january with the option of being extended further into 2022 it seems that the strategy has already paid off over 1 million passes have been issued in the past 24 hours but what is this super green pass about well Well, it's a reinforced version of the already existing green pass. Italy's health certificate showing the holder has been fully vaccinated against COVID, has recovered from the disease or has tested negative for COVID. It is normally required to access social, sporting, cultural venues. But the difference now is that the new certificate only applies to those people who've been fully vaccinated or have recovered from the disease.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Clearly, the move aims to target those people who have not been vaccinated, who won't be allowed to access a number of social venues, as you mentioned there, theatres, cinemas and so on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So, so far, the government believes that this is the best option available and the only alternative to making vaccination compulsory. Stefan? Well, it's important to note that the resistance to vaccinations will be quite expensive from now on. Tell us about the hefty fines and the public reactions to them. Well, Stefan, together with the super green pass now, mask wearing has become also compulsory in larger shopping areas. And we know the police are carrying out random green pass checks with the first fines that have been imposed today. People who don't comply with the rules risk fines between 400 and 1,000 euros.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But also doubts remain as to how to enforce the new rules on public transport.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: We know that according to the latest decree, not only the Super Green Pass has been introduced, but now passes based on testing will also be required on public transport.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So there have been a few local governors say that, for example, in the case of students, as students are not required to show the certificate when they enter schools, well, clearly that poses a problem. But the government does not want to change approach for now. As you can imagine, the latest measures have divided Italians between those who are who support the measure. They believe that they don't want to be subjected to the same restrictions as those people who have not been vaccinated.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And then you've got those people who have not been vaccinated who think that these restrictions will limit further their freedoms.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: More protests are likely to take place in the next few days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But as we've seen, when the Green Pass was extended to all workplaces, it might also happen that they will fizzle pretty soon in the next few weeks. Stefan?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: All right, Giorgio Alandi in Rome for us. Thank you very much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Germany's next Chancellor Olaf Scholz has presented his seven ministerial picks for the

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: new coalition government. The Social Democrats will take charge of several government offices, including labor and social affairs, the interior, defense and health. Scholz's pick to take on the health minister portfolio is physician Karl Lauterbach. Lauterbach, who became a firm fixture on German TV during the pandemic, takes on the job at a difficult time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Covid cases are surging, restrictions on unvaccinated people have been tightened and the possibility of mandatory vaccines is being considered.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We have to fight this pandemic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The pandemic will last longer than many think, but we will manage it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Vaccination will play the central role, but not the only role.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And in addition to that, we will strengthen the health system.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: An important aim must be to bring the case numbers down so far that we can recommend travel without endangering people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We will put emphasis on that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Great emphasis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Let's talk about the new German cabinet with Kate Brady,ady who is in berlin for us good evening kate so i gotta ask you about carl lauterbach a harvard professor and the regular on tv talk shows who has emerged as one of the country's most trusted pandemic experts um it looks like his appointment was a shoeoo-in.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, there was certainly still an element of surprise to him ultimately being appointed as a health minister today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The announcement was really hotly anticipated, more so than any previous new cabinet announcement.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: But it wasn't so much of a huge surprise, as you say.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: There had been a lot of growing support, especially on social media after his appearances on on talk shows as well but there hadn't always been that much support for him within the social democrats many of his fellow uh spd colleagues uh saying that a lot of his appearances were more about his own ego and he had also even been targeted by certain members of the far right as well, facing threats because of some of his calls at times during the pandemic for prompts and especially tighter measures in Germany's handling of the pandemic. So it was a surprise to a certain degree that he did ultimately get the job. But it seems Olaf Scholz, the designated chancellor, the designated successor to Angela Merkel, has certainly put his confidence in Karl Lauterbach.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And there wasn't all that much discontent being voiced here in Germany today about Karl Lauterbach being appointed as the health minister.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Of course, the hope now is that he will be able to put his expertise in epidemiology to good use in this role.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: If there was any discontent today, it was more at the lack of diversity now that we're seeing very clearly in the new cabinet out of 16 ministerial positions, only two people, two ministers actually come from the former east and only one minister, the agriculture minister Cem Özdemir is of migrant descent and so that really has caused some concerns here today, especially in a cabinet that was supposed to be becoming more diverse and more open compared to previous cabinets. At the same time, they have managed to just about achieve gender equality. If you take Olaf Scholz out of the equation, there are now eight men and eight women in Olaf Scholz's new cabinet.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Let me get back to Lauterbach. He is an advocate of stronger Covid measures, right?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But so was his predecessor, Jens Spahn.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Do we know what's going to change under Lauterbach?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, one of the big differences, even Jens Spahn, the outgoing health minister, said himself just at the end of last week that when the proposal to make vaccines against COVID-19 made to be mandatory, when that bill is put to the Bundestag, to the German parliament, Jens Spahn said that he's going to vote against it. This is something actually, a vaccine mandate is something that Lauterbach is very much behind and it will be on his watch now this coming week that the proposal will be put to the Bundestag and effectively in the end if it gets that far will be put into place and we're expecting if there is going to be a vaccine mandate here in Germany that could be as soon as February if not early March first of all for healthcare workers that's the expectation at least for now and then the second step what we're hearing is most likely for all citizens here in Germany, all people living here in Germany.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: At the same time, of course, the situation is developing extremely quickly right now, as we're seeing across Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And so it's certainly not completely off the cards that we could see some more measures put in place in the coming weeks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But, of course, that is something that's decided both at a federal and state level and not something that would just be decided by mr lauterbach himself all right kate brady in berlin thank you very much for this update myanmar's deposed leader aung san su chi has been given a

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: two-year prison term after being found guilty of incitement and of breaching covet 19 restrictions being found guilty of incitement and of breaching COVID-19 restrictions. Suu Kyi was originally handed a four-year sentence, but hours later it was reduced.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The verdict in this trial, widely seen as politically motivated, has been internationally condemned.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Deputy Director for Human Rights in Asia Phil Robertson told us she's sure to receive more sentences.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: It's quite clear this will be the first of many sentences that she's going to receive because the military junta in Myanmar is really piling it on her.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: There's multiple charges, even more severe than these ones, which have been brought against her and which she's being tried for.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And I expect that it's going to be the same kind of outcome, that these are politically motivated trials in front of a compromised lapdog judiciary that does what the military wants.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The international community will certainly bring out many statements of denunciation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But what they need to do is they need to impose a global arms embargo.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: They need to sanction oil and gas revenues and other revenues that are really critical for the junta to continue to operate.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And they need to put pressure on the UN Security Council to refer the situation in Myanmar to the International Criminal Court, because crimes against humanity are being committed against the people day in, day out in Myanmar.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: France's far-right presidential candidate, Éric Zemmour, promised to reconquest against decades of decline in his first electoral rally on Sunday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Scuffles broke out, with anti-racism protesters leaving at least five people injured.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Zemmour was grabbed by the neck during the rally, with a man put in custody by police.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: with a man put in custody by police. In a separate event, the French Republican Party selected Valérie Pécresse, a moderate politician from the Paris region, to challenge President Emmanuel Macron next year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It's the first time the French Republican Party picks a woman as its candidate.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Let's bring in Annelies Borges now, who has been following the presidential race in France very closely for us. So good evening, Annelies. Let now has been following the presidential race in France very closely for us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So good evening, Annelies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Let me ask you this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: If I were Emmanuel Macron, would I need to be worried about the heightened activity on the right?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: That's a very good question.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Emmanuel Macron doesn't seem to be too worried, at least for now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Very good question. Emmanuel Macron doesn't seem to be too worried, at least for now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But the contours of this race have started to be laid out.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And the most prominent names on the right are proof that France has indeed lurched towards that political side, that political side of the spectrum, the side of the political spectrum, rather. The most prominent names are coming from the right and the far right and despite skepticism from a majority of political analysts here in this country one name in particular seems to be electrifying this race so far Eric Zemmour who just like Emmanuel Macron five years ago launched his political movement and embarked on this formidable challenge to reform and perhaps reinvent France. Éric Semour is now the novelty, the novice, the fresh blood as one of his supporters told me yesterday, who seemingly out of nowhere has been gaining support and laid now his strategy. In a defiant speech yesterday in the outskirts of Paris, he kicked out his campaign, kickstarted his campaign by saying that he and his supporters, this movement, are a small grain of sand that came to clog the political machinery here in this country. He delivered a defiant message saying that he will fight for France, he will fight to reconquest France.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: He said that he wants to restore its former glory.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: It was almost like, let's make France great again.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: He said that he accused the government and the media of ostracizing him and his supporters of ignoring his message and their desires the irony could not be missed of course eric zemmour is a famous tv pundit who had his own show on french television during that speech he also laid out some of his program he talked about investing on the french industry. He talked about the creation of jobs. He talked about raising the minimum salary, also distributing bonuses for those who get the minimum pay, and explained how he will drastically reduce the number of asylum seekers allowed here in this country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Why is it that France has been pivoting so strongly to the right?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: I mean, there are now two viable candidates on the extreme right, plus the traditional center-right party now seems to have regained its footing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Indeed, many political analysts are talking about the right and are talking about this shift.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: You talked about the two far-right candidates, one being Éric Zemmour, the other one being the most traditional far-right candidate, Marine Le Pen, who inherited the far-right movement from her father, a very controversial figure here in France, and of course Valérie Pécresse in the more mainstream center right, another woman for the first time representing that camp.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Why the shift?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, there are different opinions here in France as to why that happened, but there are certainly some arguments that the right has championed throughout the years that have been gaining ground and support among voters, notably, of course, the issue of migration, one that has been populating a very divisive debate here in this country as to the size of the migrant population that is compatible with French values, just the number of migrants that should be accepted, how to include them in society, but also the issue of security that many political analysts and politicians have started to mix with that of migration. So that explosive combination is one that has been picked up by many here in this country and has been gaining ground among voters.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: What is going to be interesting to see, of course, in the next few weeks and months of this race is just how much ground this has actually gained and whether or not these people who are now saying they favor a far-right candidate will actually go to the polls and make this drastic call and vote for a far-right especially a drastic call being this being France of course all right on Elise Borges in Paris thank you very much and stay on it

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: leaders of far-right parties from across Europe have met in Warsaw to discuss how they might work together to reduce the EU's decision-making powers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But they fail to agree on forming a new political group.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Sándor Sirós reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Leaders of European far-right and populist parties have failed to agree on founding a new political group in the European Parliament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Leaders such as France's Marine Le Pen and Hungary's Viktor Orban attended the high-level meeting in Warsaw over the weekend, but they left with just a statement highlighting the need for closer cooperation against the power of the Brussels institutions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It is not the commissioners, it is not the administration, and it is not the bureaucrats or the directors in the European Commission who will decide how we should live.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: If the radical populist parties were to unite in the European Parliament, they could form the third biggest political group, giving them some serious influence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But despite agreeing on issues of national sovereignty, migration and Euroscepticism, the ruling Polish Law and Justice Party is reluctant to join because they could lose influence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: While identity and democracy and its member parties are largely isolated in the European Parliament, the European Conservatives and Reformists and especially Law and Justice isn't.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: They have reporters, shadow reporters in the European Parliament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: ECR also has a committee presidency.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But there are also issues they disagreed on, like relations with Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: While Francis Le Pen has close ties with Putin, Poland is in the opposite camp.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: There are also internal divisions like in Italy between La Lega and the Brothers of Italy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: In the short term, EU mainstream parties shouldn't be worried.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: This is now a lar pur lar media happening.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The one thing which benefits all of the participants is that they can shape the political agenda, they can get media attention, and that's the whole reason behind this repeated radical right forums throughout the year, which always fail to produce any kind of tangible results.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The parties involved say they will organize the next conference in Spain within the following months.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Sándor Zsíros, Euronews, Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The southernmost tip of the world has experienced

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: the only total solar eclipse of 2021.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But apart from a small group of people, only the local wildlife witnessed it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Rebecca Daunt reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: This rare astronomical spectacle was experienced in Antarctica by just a handful of scientists, tourists and the odd penguin or two.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The frozen continent, currently in the height of its summer season, was plunged into darkness on Saturday morning.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Solar eclipses occur when the moon passes between the sun and the earth, casting a striking shadow, blocking out the light of the Sun.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: For an eclipse to be total, the Sun, Moon and Earth must directly align.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The last total solar eclipse occurred in Antarctica in 2003.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The next one is not expected until 2039.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Tens of thrill-seekers, who paid 35,000 euro for the privilege, braced the icy temperatures from the Union Glacier Camp, some 1,000 kilometres north of the South Pole.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: According to NASA, a partial eclipse was also visible in parts of the southern hemisphere, including Lesotho, South Africa, Chile and Australia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: That's it for this edition. Thank you for watching. See you next time.
